The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

. •. •
Gridiron Gossip 11
When the good ship Johns
Hopkins hoisted anchor for its
present journey and learned that
the cruisers St. John's and Maryland were lying in wait, a shudder went up from the crew. For
the Johns Hopkins men were as
yet untried, they did not know
their prowess, they were not
versed in the ways of the sea and
they had heard tales of the ability of the opponents, of the
strength of the opposing crew, of
the sagacity of the opposing captains.
When the Black and Blue ship
was defeated in its first encounter and given blow for blow in its
second, the fears mounted. Soon,
however, the men began to realize their own prowess and in
their third and fourth encounters
the opposing vessels, George
Washington and Haverford were
sunk.
Despite the stupendous tales
concerning St. John's and Maryland, they did not show up well in
their encounters; their men were
iot as powerful as had been rumored, their captains not as wise.
So that now the crew of the
good ship Johns Hopkins is eag,rly awaiting first sight of the opposing cruisers with all hands on
deck.
Princeton is the only team in
the East that has not had its goal
:ine crossed. But they don't play
Chicago until tomorrow. We are
thinking that the debit side of the
ledger will show a few marks on
Saturday night.
----Plenty of work on hand for the
dopester tomorrow. Any man that
can figure out the result of the
Army-Yale, Harvard-Dartmouth,
Navy - Pennsylvania, Chicago Princeton and other games is
wasting his time following football.
It was a shame to disappoint
Haverford on Saturday. They had
a nice big bonfire all ready to light
and then we had to win. Inconsiderate!
Gilmore Dobie of Cornell and
Curley Byrd of Maryland ought
to get together and talk things
over. The former making two or
three exceptions, refuses to sign
a contract unless the opposing
team guarantees 65 points. Curley, on the other hand, sets 15
points as his season's aggregate
maximum. We'll help you keep
down your score, Maryland.

INTERFRATERNITY BOARD
MEETS
The regular weekly meeting of
the Interfraternity Board was held
on Monday at 12:20. The board
discussed several, until now, rather
obscure points of the rushing agreement, particularly With regard to
entertaining freshmen. It was decided that it would be a breach of
the agreement for freshmen to attend an 'entertainment at the home
of an alumnus, or any entertainment given by an alumnus.
In order to consider some necessary business that could not be
taken up on Monday for lack of
time, a meeting was called for tonight. The meeting will be held
at the Phi Gamma Delta House,
4225 Wickford Road, at 7:30 P. M.

THE JOHNS HO PK ENS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 27, 1922.
FACULTY NOTES
President Goodnow and Bryson Bright represented the Johns
Hopkins University at the inauguration of Dr. Marion Edward
Park as president of Bryn Mawr
College, October 21.
Last Monday the students in
Political Economy were startled
to find most of the members of
that faculty absent. However, instead of a vacation or even the
Usual lecture, quizzes were had
by all. There was not a strike of
the faculty. Four of the professors motored to Wachapreag,ue,
Va., where it is rumored they
spent the time fishing. It is presumed that they were really engaged in a practical experiment
of the story of the fisherman on
the island, With which all students of Poly Con I are familiar.
DORMS PROGRESSING
RAPIDLY
The Johns Hopkins dormitory is
moving rapidly on its way towards
completion. The builders are working early and late on the structure
and promise to have it completed
by next June. The foundations
have been set up and the men now
are working on the first floor.
The building will be large, with
a housing capacity of 300 students.
It will be built of spot-face brick,
heated by steam, and will be three
stories in height.
This dormitory will be quite exclusive and among the best in the
country. In many colleges and universities the dormitories are a good
distance from the school. Having
the dormitory at such a good location as has been chosen for this
one, a great amount of time will
be saved in going to and from the
University. A large dining room
will be located on the first floor.
Each student will have a study and
a bedroom.
This dormitory should hold all
.the students from out-of-town and
their housing problems will be
brought to an end.

At the annual convention of the
Maryland Baptist Young People's Union held recently at Brantly Baptist Church, Hamilton C.
Davis, who graduated from Hopkins in 1920, was elected president

noon at the Synagogue House.
The smoker was well attended
and an enjoyable afternoon was

FRESHMEN HAVE PROMISING GRID TEAM
The Freshman football team, as
well as the Varsity team, is practicing every afternoon at the athletic field. "Vic" Noyes, who was
a star player at the Naval Academy.
is coaching the team, and under his
direction the Freshies should round
into a well-balanced machine in a
short time.
The Freshmen were late in starting this year, but despite this handicap have shown up well. There
are about twenty-five candidates
out for the team. With such a number, two elevens can be picked for
scrimmage. A few men on the
squad have shown quite a little ability in punting and running with the
ball.
So far the team has not played
any games, but Manager Hess is
trying to arrange scrimmages with
local elevens. As yet no captain
has been elected.

TRACK TEAM SCANDAL!
Last April when the track team
was returning from its Southern
trip, the train stopped for five hours
at a small town, Basic, Va. A certain member of the team met the
only girl in town, a very attractive
young lady, and took her to a dance.
After the dance he introduced the
young lady to the coach and the
rest of the team.
During the summer, some one
connected with the team in an official capacity received a pink, perfumed letter, addressed in care of
his wife. The suspicions of the
team, however, are entirely unjustified.

McNEIL APPOINTED BASEBALL COACH
Norman McNeil, who is well
known in Baltimore, has signed a
contract to coach the Hopkins baseball team next spring. He will take
the place of Herbert Armstrong,
who has hard charge of the team
for the past two years.
McNeil has been playing professional ball for some time. For
awhile he caught for the Boston
Red Sox. From that team he went
to the Jersey City club of the International League, where he was
the mainstay at the receiving end
during the 1921 season. This past
year he played ball only during the
latter part of the season, when he
joined the Reading Club. He has
ilso played with the Baltimore Dry
Docks organization. At the end
-)f the collegiate year McNeil will
join the Columbus club of the
American Association.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

. •. •
Gridiron Gossip 11
When the good ship Johns
Hopkins hoisted anchor for its
present journey and learned that
the cruisers St. John's and Maryland were lying in wait, a shudder went up from the crew. For
the Johns Hopkins men were as
yet untried, they did not know
their prowess, they were not
versed in the ways of the sea and
they had heard tales of the ability of the opponents, of the
strength of the opposing crew, of
the sagacity of the opposing captains.
When the Black and Blue ship
was defeated in its first encounter and given blow for blow in its
second, the fears mounted. Soon,
however, the men began to realize their own prowess and in
their third and fourth encounters
the opposing vessels, George
Washington and Haverford were
sunk.
Despite the stupendous tales
concerning St. John's and Maryland, they did not show up well in
their encounters; their men were
iot as powerful as had been rumored, their captains not as wise.
So that now the crew of the
good ship Johns Hopkins is eag,rly awaiting first sight of the opposing cruisers with all hands on
deck.
Princeton is the only team in
the East that has not had its goal
:ine crossed. But they don't play
Chicago until tomorrow. We are
thinking that the debit side of the
ledger will show a few marks on
Saturday night.
----Plenty of work on hand for the
dopester tomorrow. Any man that
can figure out the result of the
Army-Yale, Harvard-Dartmouth,
Navy - Pennsylvania, Chicago Princeton and other games is
wasting his time following football.
It was a shame to disappoint
Haverford on Saturday. They had
a nice big bonfire all ready to light
and then we had to win. Inconsiderate!
Gilmore Dobie of Cornell and
Curley Byrd of Maryland ought
to get together and talk things
over. The former making two or
three exceptions, refuses to sign
a contract unless the opposing
team guarantees 65 points. Curley, on the other hand, sets 15
points as his season's aggregate
maximum. We'll help you keep
down your score, Maryland.

INTERFRATERNITY BOARD
MEETS
The regular weekly meeting of
the Interfraternity Board was held
on Monday at 12:20. The board
discussed several, until now, rather
obscure points of the rushing agreement, particularly With regard to
entertaining freshmen. It was decided that it would be a breach of
the agreement for freshmen to attend an 'entertainment at the home
of an alumnus, or any entertainment given by an alumnus.
In order to consider some necessary business that could not be
taken up on Monday for lack of
time, a meeting was called for tonight. The meeting will be held
at the Phi Gamma Delta House,
4225 Wickford Road, at 7:30 P. M.

THE JOHNS HO PK ENS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 27, 1922.
FACULTY NOTES
President Goodnow and Bryson Bright represented the Johns
Hopkins University at the inauguration of Dr. Marion Edward
Park as president of Bryn Mawr
College, October 21.
Last Monday the students in
Political Economy were startled
to find most of the members of
that faculty absent. However, instead of a vacation or even the
Usual lecture, quizzes were had
by all. There was not a strike of
the faculty. Four of the professors motored to Wachapreag,ue,
Va., where it is rumored they
spent the time fishing. It is presumed that they were really engaged in a practical experiment
of the story of the fisherman on
the island, With which all students of Poly Con I are familiar.
DORMS PROGRESSING
RAPIDLY
The Johns Hopkins dormitory is
moving rapidly on its way towards
completion. The builders are working early and late on the structure
and promise to have it completed
by next June. The foundations
have been set up and the men now
are working on the first floor.
The building will be large, with
a housing capacity of 300 students.
It will be built of spot-face brick,
heated by steam, and will be three
stories in height.
This dormitory will be quite exclusive and among the best in the
country. In many colleges and universities the dormitories are a good
distance from the school. Having
the dormitory at such a good location as has been chosen for this
one, a great amount of time will
be saved in going to and from the
University. A large dining room
will be located on the first floor.
Each student will have a study and
a bedroom.
This dormitory should hold all
.the students from out-of-town and
their housing problems will be
brought to an end.

FRESHMEN HAVE PROMISING GRID TEAM
The Freshman football team, as
well as the Varsity team, is practicing every afternoon at the athletic field. "Vic" Noyes, who was
a star player at the Naval Academy.
is coaching the team, and under his
direction the Freshies should round
into a well-balanced machine in a
short time.
The Freshmen were late in starting this year, but despite this handicap have shown up well. There
are about twenty-five candidates
out for the team. With such a number, two elevens can be picked for
scrimmage. A few men on the
squad have shown quite a little ability in punting and running with the
ball.
So far the team has not played
any games, but Manager Hess is
trying to arrange scrimmages with
local elevens. As yet no captain
has been elected.

TRACK TEAM SCANDAL!
Last April when the track team
was returning from its Southern
trip, the train stopped for five hours
at a small town, Basic, Va. A certain member of the team met the
only girl in town, a very attractive
young lady, and took her to a dance.
After the dance he introduced the
young lady to the coach and the
rest of the team.
During the summer, some one
connected with the team in an official capacity received a pink, perfumed letter, addressed in care of
his wife. The suspicions of the
team, however, are entirely unjustified.

known in Baltimore, has signed a
contract to coach the Hopkins baseball team next spring. He will take
the place of Herbert Armstrong,
who has hard charge of the team
for the past two years.
McNeil has been playing professional ball for some time. For
awhile he caught for the Boston
Red Sox. From that team he went
to the Jersey City club of the International League, where he was
the mainstay at the receiving end
during the 1921 season. This past
year he played ball only during the
latter part of the season, when he
joined the Reading Club. He has
ilso played with the Baltimore Dry
Docks organization. At the end
-)f the collegiate year McNeil will
join the Columbus club of the
American Association.
